facts.text: Khashaba Maruti Shelke, aged 33, tried with eight others by Sessions Judge Sangli for offences under sections 302/34, 307/34 etc. IPC and Arms Act, Explosive Substances Act.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted eight accused and convicted appellant under section 302 IPC on two counts for deaths of Head Constable Yesade (45) and Smt. Balkabai (70), sentenced to death on each count.

issues.text: The crucial question which arises for determination in the present case is whether the appellant possessed the hand-grenade in question and exploded the same, as a result of which injuries were caused to the two deceased persons and the different police officials.

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question which arises for determination in the present case is whether the appellant possessed the, hand- grenade in question and exploded the same, as a result of which injuries were caused to the two deceased persons and the different police officials.

issues.text: Whether the appellant can be convicted again under sections 25 and 27 of the Arms Act for possession of the same rifle and cartridges given prior conviction in connection with the firing at Jaising.
Whether the circumstantial evidence relied upon by the High Court is sufficient to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the appellant exploded the hand-grenade.

arguments.claim: Plea of denial simpliciter; absconded due to fear of Shankar Bhima Patil who was related to accused in murder case where appellant's father was witness; injuries caused during grappling with police at noon on July 27

anchor.surface_text: At the trial the plea of the appellant was denial simpliciter. According to the appellant, he had left his village because be was afraid of one Shankar Bhima Patil. Shankar Bhima Patil was stated to be a relation of an accused in a murder case and the father of the appellant had appeared as a prosecution witness against that accused. As regards the injuries on his person, the appellant stated that he was apprehended by the police in a field at about noon time on July 27, 1970.

arguments.court_reasoning: circumstantial evidence admits of rational explanations including alternatives

arguments.claim: Appellant exploded the hand-grenade and caused the different injuries

anchor.surface_text: The trial court convicted the appellant as mentioned above because it was of the view that the appellant had exploded the hand. grenade and had caused the different injuries. The High Court on appeal and reference substantially agreed with the trial court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rein two persons were killed and a number of others were injured, number direct evidence companyld be produced as to who had exploded the handgrenade

arguments.court_reasoning: case not proved beyond reasonable doubt; circumstantial evidence not conclusive

arguments.claim: Case has not been proved against appellant beyond all reasonable doubt

anchor.surface_text: We have heard in appeal Mr. Srivastava on behalf of the appellant and Mr. Khanna on behalf of the State, and are of the view that the case has not been proved against the appellant beyond all reasonable doubt. The fact that a hand-grenade was exploded in the house of Ananda when the police party

arguments.claim: Appellant absconding in two murder cases proves possession and explosion of hand-grenade

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in maintaining the conviction of the appellant has relied upon the following pieces of circumstantial evidence The fact that the appellant was absconding before the occurrence in two murder cases. The fact that the appellant was seen carrying a gun and cartridges in village Kavathe-Piran by Head Constable Naik on July, 25, 1970.

arguments.court_reasoning: does not necessarily show appellant exploded grenade; companions equally interested in preventing apprehension

arguments.claim: Appellant seen carrying gun and cartridges on July 25 proves possession and explosion of hand-grenade

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the appellant was seen carrying a gun and cartridges in village Kavathe-Piran by Head Constable Naik on July, 25, 1970. The fact that the appellant fired at Jaising at 9 p.m. on July 26, 1970 in village Kavathe-Piran. The fact that the appellant sought shelter in The house-of Appa Kesre at about mid-night hour after the explosion of the handgrenade.

arguments.court_reasoning: circumstances taken singly or cumulatively do not show appellant exploded hand-grenade

arguments.claim: Appellant fired at Jaising proves possession and explosion of hand-grenade

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the appellant fired at Jaising at 9 p.m. on July 26, 1970 in village Kavathe-Piran. The fact that the appellant sought shelter in The house-of Appa Kesre at about mid-night hour after the explosion of the handgrenade. The fact that the appellant had abrasions on his person at the time of his arrest and his underwear was found to be stained with blood.

arguments.court_reasoning: no inference that hand-grenade exploded by appellant

arguments.claim: Appellant sought shelter in Appa Kesre's house after explosion proves he exploded hand-grenade

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the appellant sought shelter in The house-of Appa Kesre at about mid-night hour after the explosion of the handgrenade. The fact that the appellant had abrasions on his person at the time of his arrest and his underwear was found to be stained with blood. In our opinion, the circumstances enumerated above taken singly or cumulatively do not go to show that it was the appellant who exploded the hand-grenade.

arguments.court_reasoning: does not lead to inference appellant exploded grenade

arguments.claim: Appellant had abrasions and blood-stained underwear proves he exploded hand-grenade
arguments.court_reasoning: does not show appellant rather than companion exploded grenade

arguments.claim: Appellant accompanied by others but he exploded hand-grenade

anchor.surface_text: It is in the evidence of Jaising PW 21 that the appellant on the night of occurrence was accompanied by four other persons, namely, Ramchandra, Mane Shankar and Sadashiv. Out of them, Shankar and Sadashiv were strangers. Ramchandra and Mane were also charged for the various offences for which the appellant was charged, but they were acquitted.

arguments.court_reasoning: nothing rules out companion exploding grenade

arguments.claim: Appellant's brother Jallandar ex-army untraceable since incident and grenade service origin proves appellant possessed and exploded it
arguments.court_reasoning: far from showing appellant alone possessed; could procure through other illegal sources

arguments.claim: Police entries Ex.139 and Ex.162 intelligence that appellant carried hand-grenade proves possession
arguments.court_reasoning: hearsay no direct knowledge; persons not examined; cannot substitute substantive witness evidence

arguments.claim: Cannot convict again under Arms Act ss.25 and 27 for possession of same rifle and cartridges as prior conviction in Jaising case
No bullet injury on deceased or police proves rifle not used to cause injuries
FIR by Head Constable Naik omits mention of hand-grenade explosion despite reference to tear gas
No direct evidence because prosecution arraigned inmates of Ananda's house as accused preventing their examination as witnesses
Circumstantial evidence must be consistent only with guilt, exclude rational alternatives, form complete chain or accused gets benefit of doubt

holdings.text: the case has not been proved against the appellant beyond all reasonable doubt

anchor.surface_text: We have heard in appeal Mr. Srivastava on behalf of the appellant and Mr. Khanna on behalf of the State, and are of the view that the case has not been proved against the appellant beyond all reasonable doubt. The fact that a hand-grenade was exploded in the house of Ananda when the police party

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstantial evidence taken singly or cumulatively does not conclusively establish appellant's possession and explosion of hand-grenade; admits rational alternatives by companions

holdings.text: the circumstances enumerated above taken singly or cumulatively do not go to show that it was the appellant who exploded the hand-grenade
holdings.reasoning_summary: Absconding status, carrying arms, firing at Jaising, seeking shelter, abrasions do not exclude possibility of companions exploding grenade to aid escape

holdings.text: As the appellant has already been convicted for the offences under the Arms Act for being in possession of the rifle and the cartridges, he cannot be convicted again for being in possession of the same rifle and cartridges on that day
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior conviction in separate case for same possession on same occasion bars double conviction; no bullet injuries prove rifle not used to injure

holdings.text: It also cannot be said that the appellant caused any injury with the, rifle to the two deceased persons or the other police officials because no bullet injury was found on any one of them
holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-mortem and injury reports confirm no bullet wounds on deceased or injured police, inconsistent with rifle use

holdings.text: In order to base the conviction of an accused on circumstantial evidence the court must be certain that the circumstantial evidence is, of such a character as is consistent only with the guilt of the accused... there must be a chain of evidence so far complete as not to leave any reasonable ground for a conclusion consistent with the innocence of the accused
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies established doctrine requiring circumstantial evidence to form complete chain excluding innocence hypotheses; present evidence fails test

anchor.surface_text: We have heard in appeal Mr. Srivastava on behalf of the appellant and Mr. Khanna on behalf of the State, and are of the view that the case has number been proved against the appellant beyond all reasonable doubt.

outcome.relief_summary: Case not proved beyond reasonable doubt; circumstantial evidence does not establish that appellant exploded the hand-grenade or caused the injuries and deaths; convictions under sections 302, 307, 333, 332 IPC, Arms Act, and Explosive Substances Act set aside as not warranted
